This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies.  This program has been coordinated with the local emergency services including: Salt Lake City Fire Department + HAZMAT Team, Salt Lake County LEPC, and the local emergency management services agency.

The facility's Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

 --  Key Plant Personnel and Responsibilities
 --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
 --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
 --  First Aid Procedures
 --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
 --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
 --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
 --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
 --  Incident Command System
 --  Initial and Refresher Training


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe work environment. Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Committee Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Corporate Danone North America - SLC representatives also provide guidance and assistance for the facility personnel to ensure outstanding issues are resolved, and that the facility remains in compliance.  Danone North America - SLC also plans to improve safety as follows:

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

--  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
--  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia over the past five years (May 2017 - May 2022) that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a release of ammonia.

Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration system is a top priority for Danone North America - SLC.  The management plan, internal audits, Process Hazard Analysis studies, as well as our prevention programs are monitored and updated as appropriate to ensure that all elements of our PSM/RMP policy remain accurate and complete.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Danone North America - SLC facility and is maintained by the EHS Manager.  It is based on OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plan (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and HAZWOPER (29 CFR 1910.

To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties at the plant for each element of the facility's PSM / RMP program.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential compliance issues and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC) and the local Salt Lake City Fire Department.  The ultimate goal for Danone North America's PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid physical damage to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate a refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern our network of ammonia refrigeration facilities, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry.

The Danone North America - SLC ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Danone North America - SLC facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  Safety features include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room, continuous automated ventilation, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, and emergency stop controls.  The majority of the ammonia inventory is centrally located inside the machine room.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with pressure relie

s operate continuously and are designed for exhaust rates which exceed the emergency exhaust requirements.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to address system heat load demands during operation.  The machinery room houses the compressors, high pressure receiver vessel, recirculator package with pumps, and auxiliary components, while the condensers are located on the roof along with evaporator valve groups and associated piping.

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from cold storage zones, and secondary coolants (glycol) to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers, where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor, causing it to condense to a liquid.

Multiple surge drums / recirculator packages are utilized to service the various refrigerated zones at the facility that include palletizing, secondary packaging, bottle storage cooler, as well as chilling glycol via three (3) heat exchangers.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia system including:  ammonia leak detection, auto purger to remove non-condensible gasses, pressure relief system, and refrigeration control system.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

onsible for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Danone North America - Salt Lake City facility was re-commissioned in June 2017 following a change in ownership.  The facility is located approximately ¾ mile north of State Highway 201 and approximately 0.4 miles west of State Highway 154 (4000W).

Danone North America - SLC manufactures, packages, and distributes food (dairy) products and uses the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system (closed-loop process) for cold storage logistics operations, and process fluid cooling.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 13,750 pounds.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

For example, all compressors are routinely inspected for oil leaks, pressure and temperature gauge calibrations, vibration analysis, oil pressure, and amp reading for motors;  alignment of compressor motors and bearings, filter changes, vibration readings are performed every 6 months on compressor motors;  the condensers are inspected weekly (this includes checking and cleaning nozzles and strainers), motors are greased, fans are checked for cracks, and piping is inspected for leaks;  low and intermediate pressure receiver oil pots are drained, pump bearing wear is monitored;  visual inspection for equipment and vessel operating limit conditions, piping and valves are assessed for leaks, integrity, and other potential abnormalities on daily basis;  pressure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency.  Ammonia leak detectors are calibrated semi-annually and trigger local audible and visual alarms for plant personnel.  Machinery room ventilation system

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

WWF Operating Company, LLC (Danone North America - SLC) recognizes the facility's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Danone North America - SLC is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at Danone North America - SLC. 

It is Danone North America's policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable plant personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare plant personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

The Salt Lake City facility draws from decades of internal experience and expertise, as well as resources of our parent company, Danone North America, to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the plant's safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).
